channel.title: The Blackmailed Spy [Another ToL Merlin Attempt]
channel.description:
> # [color=ligblue]The Spy[/color] > [color=ligblue]**Blue Dragon Social**[/color] > > **Undercover (Passive) -** You know who the Mastermind and Cult Leader are at all times. > > **Blackmailed (Passive) -** > - You cannot vote against the Mastermind or Cult Leader, execute them, whisper, or talk while imprisoned, linked, or conduited. > - If executed during the day or by Prince at night, you will appear to be The Fool and the punishment (or lack thereof) is the same as executing an actual fool. > - Any Unseen or Cult who execute or attack you will appear **not suspicious** to investigatives that night.
> # [color=cc33F]The Double Agent[/color] > [color=cc33F]**Unseen Social**[/color] > >**Undercover (Passive) -** You always appear as not suspicious to the Sheriff and Observer, and as a Social or Support class to the Princess. This passive is kept when your class changes. > >**Slander (Day) -** Make the player on trial appear as their converted counterpart, if they are able to be converted. (1 use) > >**Blackmail (Night) -** Make a player unable to vote against the Unseen, and force them to pardon if any Unseen are put on trial. (2 uses)
# #RoastMe

item.source: The Blackmailed Spy [Another ToL Merlin Attempt]

item.title: The Blackmailed Spy [Another ToL Merlin Attempt]
item.dc:creator: iSocket
item.description:
You’ve pitched this class as being a Merlin equivalent, but you’ve completely disregarded Merlin’s drawback. In The Resistance: Avalon, Merlin knows who all the evil players are, but the evils get a chance to guess who Merlin is at the end of the game, even if they lose. If they guess correctly, the evils win. If Merlin just outs who all the evils are, but then the evils just call out Merlin for being obvious Merlin, the good team still loses.

There is nothing stopping The Spy here from just outing who the evils are. The drawbacks you’ve listed here are by far not enough to compensate for perfect information on who the evil players are. If you dropped this class into Throne as it exists, all Spies would just say, protect/jail me, X is MM/CL and then the next day do the same thing to the new MM/CL when you vote the first one out. Evils have no counterplay and games would devolve to NK hunts very quickly.

This just doesn’t work.

Read full topic
item.source: The Blackmailed Spy [Another ToL Merlin Attempt]

item.title: The Blackmailed Spy [Another ToL Merlin Attempt]
item.dc:creator: Geyde
item.description:
Shrimpy:

So Blue Dragon loses if spy is revealed, but Unseen loses if they are incorrect about who spy is (nothing happens if they take no guess).

Reading about Merlin you will find experienced players say he isn’t actually that swingy when players are experienced and there are a sufficient number of players

About your experienced player point, I would be inclined to agree despite my lack of experience on the topic. But that’s beside the point.

If there were an alternative mode to ToL’s main mode, sure. This could be slotted into there.

As is, it warps the main game too much alongisde the varying skill that comes with a lack of a skill-based matchmaking system.

Read full topic
item.source: The Blackmailed Spy [Another ToL Merlin Attempt]

item.title: The Blackmailed Spy [Another ToL Merlin Attempt]
item.dc:creator: Shrimpy
item.description:
So Blue Dragon loses if spy is revealed, but Unseen loses if they are incorrect about who spy is (nothing happens if they take no guess).

Reading about Merlin you will find experienced players say he isn’t actually that swingy when players are experienced and there are a sufficient number of players (16 is more than enough for a class that isn’t even guaranteed to spawn).

It’s only a problem for noobs, but that is easily remedied by not letting noobs player as Merlin or play as the evil class which is assigned to guess him.

Read full topic
item.source: The Blackmailed Spy [Another ToL Merlin Attempt]

item.title: The Blackmailed Spy [Another ToL Merlin Attempt]
item.dc:creator: Shrimpy
item.description:
I agree that is the only balanced counterplay. But I strongly disagree it would be unfun. Avalon and Mindnight have game modes like this already. And you can’t even eliminate the Merlin in those games because there is no player elimination.

Read full topic
item.source: The Blackmailed Spy [Another ToL Merlin Attempt]

item.title: The Blackmailed Spy [Another ToL Merlin Attempt]
item.dc:creator: Geyde
item.description:
The only way a Merlin can work is if scum have serious counterplay.
This counterplay in the context of ToL would have to be ‘if someone knows you are Merlin, you die and lynches are blocked for [x] days’

But even then it’s just unfun

Read full topic
item.source: The Blackmailed Spy [Another ToL Merlin Attempt]

item.title: The Blackmailed Spy [Another ToL Merlin Attempt]
item.dc:creator: Geyde
item.description:
Arete:
Shrimpy:

Undercover (Passive) - You know who the Mastermind and Cult Leader are at all times.

You literally just out yourself D2 and say who the MM/CL is.

Then when they get executed you repeat this.

If necessary the Prince can chain-jail you until both MMs are gone, or until all CLs are gone.

Shrimpy:

They appear to be whatever class they claimed to be in their logs.

The technical limitations of ToL prohibit this class from working, alongside the very design of the game being a rolemadness without any counterplay by scum themselves.

But I’m not going to talk about that.
It’s immediately fairly obvious.

I’ll look at this from Unseen/Cult pov
By this class existing, they are forced into a constant state of being confirmed scum to one player from the start of the game.
No matter what you do, you can’t avoid the fact that someone knows this.

It’s the definition of unfun gameplay.

Read full topic
item.source: The Blackmailed Spy [Another ToL Merlin Attempt]
